Posts.Content: Hi ladies, I am kind of facing the same problem at the moment and finding the subject a bit of a mine field. I finished Tamoxifen around this time last year, it was my surgeon that said it was time to come off the Tamoxifen (which I could not wait to get back to a kind of normal ) I was feeling really well, came off it there was no mention of after care for my periods coming back or blood test to check the oestrogen levels or anything, was told will see you in a year, well done! It was only till I started having panic attacks out of the blue that my nightmare started and has gone on ever since, only now am I getting them to listen to me instead of being told that I am worrying about nothing and it's normal to feel like that when you finish treatment. There is the problem now of what to do with me as I was hormone positive and my periods have come back although in stops and starts and my hormones are very out of balance, I think I am perimenopausal along with suffering from pmt ( badly ), it astounds me that they can't work it out, but instead they hand you out antidepressants, what a way to finish my all in all good treatment for breast cancer!!!! So it still begs the question do I have the ovaries out to A. stop the cancer coming there and B. Help balance out my body and heavy periods. Sorry Tinker's I have not answered your question but only raised my own. Ruby xxxx
Posts.Title: Anyone had ovaries removed as a precaution?

Posts.Content: Sorry for the late reply Wildbreast, I'm with you on the group idea, I think this is a very specific area of after care that should be aimed at breast or gynaecological cancers and there should be more training given to GP's, nursing staff and consultants, it's not enough to be shown the door at thought that you are going mad and not coping after cancer, there is so much more to it, to be faced with phoning a cancer help line looking for help, only to be told it's perfectly normal to feel this way when treatment is over is just not good enough!!!! Sorry rant over. Would love to help Wildbreast Ruby xx
Posts.Title: Anyone had ovaries removed as a precaution?

Posts.Content: I think your onc is probably right, the only thing with taking them out is of coarse it puts you straight into menopause and for me a little bit of the unknown and am I opening up a whole lot of new problems, life at the moment for me has stood still since coming off Tamoxifen and there was me thinking I was going to start a whole new healthy life after treatment, some days I feel so awful and sad that I am still swimming through mud and in some way's doing the doctors work for them, treatment for breast cancer was the easy part and it makes me feel very sad and angry that women are still not having the proper aftercare they so rightly deserve. Ruby xx
Posts.Title: Anyone had ovaries removed as a precaution?

Posts.Content: I'm sorry but I have to agree with Carol, if it saves just one woman then in my book it's worth it and it's about time we stopped being negative about breast screening. Roobs
Posts.Title: breast screening - real facts

Posts.Content: That is precisely my point, not every cancer or person is the same. Roobs
Posts.Title: breast screening - real facts

Posts.Content: Morning Kay, I took tamoxifen for five years, started it when I was 35 and although the chemo had stopped my periods the tamoxifen pretty much finished them off. There were times I had bleeds but I think it is quite common for some women . If you are worried tell your breast care nurse, but I am sure its fine. All the best Ruby500 xxx
Posts.Title: tamoxifen and periods

Posts.Content: Hi Cricha Please don't feel you are on your own. As you know I also suffer from panic attacks and know how scary they are, but we both know nothing bad can happen. Your daughter is away for a week, if I were you I'd take each day at a time, try and keep yourself busy, I know how hard it is, I am also going though it. You sound like you are getting out and about (driving). I have not been able to drive by myself for two months now (although I am getting help now). Have you a close friend that you can trust that lives not too far that can support you? Lots of hugs  Ruby xx
Posts.Title: am i being selfish

Posts.Content: Hi  Wendy,  I had AC back in 2004 every 3 weeks and although it is not nice to be on I found that it shrunk my  tumour and did what it was meant to do and I am still here. I also had taxotere which I found much easier to take than AC.  If you have any questions I will be more than happy to try and help. Ruby xx
Posts.Title: AC Chemo followed by Taxotere

Posts.Content: That's good, glad it wasn't a problem, I'm sure they have seen much worse things on scans and xrays!!!!! Ruby x
Posts.Title: CT during period

Posts.Content: Hi Rebecca, That's a really good question, if I were you I'd just phone them up in the morning and ask or phone the macmillan nurses, I don't think the tampon will matter but good to check. Ruby x
Posts.Title: CT during period

Posts.Content: Hello Pat, I just wanted to send you some much needed strength for your results tomorrow, and although everyone's journey is personal, one thing I keep finding is that we all share an inner strength (yes you have it too). Whatever the results are tomorrow your going to be in the brilliant care of the most fantastic people who will do their very best for you, and us ladies who have been there already will be with you holding your hand. Ruby xxxxx
Posts.Title: Waiting game

Posts.Content: Hi Wend76 I am on a very similar medication called Decapeptyl, it does the same thing as zoladex closes down the ovaries to stop the production of estrogen which my breast cancer was dependant on, so when I came off tamoxifen a year and half ago it was decided that I was going into prei menopause which was causing all kinds of problems, so I'm on a test run to see if I can cope with early menopause. I'm on my second injection and I am having similar pain to yourself, shoulder joints,  wrists, balls of my feet, and at times it becomes too painful to move my wrists, I have been taking flaxseed oil, also B vitamins and I  try to keep moving, I try not to take pain killers as they block me up, but the flaxseed is wonderful , I try and get my calcium intake from lots of vegetables as I don't eat much dairy. Hope that helps x Ruby500
Posts.Title: Zoladex and joint pain

Posts.Content: Hi Jo,  Please don't despair I had Taxotere and experienced tummy cramps and diarrhoea, Im surprised they did not warn you about this, it can also give you flu like symptoms. Keep drinking loads of fluids, water is best and have plenty of rest , but try not to get too stiff ( if that makes sense try and have a daily walk. Hope this helps and please don't get down, we are all there holding your hand ; ) Ruby xxxxxx
Posts.Title: Taxotere side effects

Posts.Content: Try and stay away from too much dairy and fatty foods, eat plenty of veg and if you can make some veg soup. Hope that helps, sorry your feeling rubbish Ruby xxx
Posts.Title: Taxotere side effects

Posts.Content: Mishka ,  That's great news, you must be so relieved and like Ellen has said don't ever apologise for news like that, its just so nice to get such a happy result. Ruby xxxxx
Posts.Title: Got my results...

Posts.Content: Morning Annabel, Just wanted to wish you well for scan today and I'm sure chemo tomorrow will go fine tomorrow. Sending lots of love & hugs Ruby xxxx
Posts.Title: First chemo tomorrow

Posts.Content: Hi Jess,  There is a web site called breastcancer.org  It has loads of information about surgery.  Hope this helps Take care  Ruby xx
Posts.Title: Mastectomy help

Posts.Content: I have just spoken to my breast care nurse and she has advised that maybe I come off the Tamoxifen for six weeks so they can check my hormone levels to see whether I have gone through the menopause, I will be 44 come December. She told me that Tamoxifen can cause low moods because it blocks the oestrogen, so I guess that makes a whole lot of sense. Has anyone else had the menopause test done????? Ruby x
Posts.Title: Tamoxifen second time around

Posts.Content: Hello everyone it's been a long time since I have been on this site and a lot of the ladies that were on here a few years ago have probably moved on by now, It's been a long time since I was diagnosed way back in 2005 and I have been put back on Tamoxifen for the second time around but Im sure it's making me feel very down has anyone else experienced this???Enter your message...
Posts.Title: Tamoxifen second time around

Posts.Content: Hi Helen That's a very good point you have made, I will be keeping a note of which one I'm on. I'm on anti depression tablets as I have anxiety also, only been on them for about three weeks, so hoping they will make a difference, hate all of this though, plus hot flushes are back and are very bad, but the doctor can't give me anything for that. Thanks Helen for your reply x
Posts.Title: Tamoxifen second time around

Posts.Content: Hi Lonefox, How are you doing? Hope you had a peaceful Christmas and  a Happy New Year to you! The acid is awful and can be painful as I have suffered with it too. Ask your GP for a drug called lansoprazole, they will help with the acid and eat  bland food nothing spicy and stay away from onions also try not to eat anything with high fat as your tummy will only have difficulty breaking it down and therefore producing more acid which will then cause more discomfort . Drink loads of water and try a little bit of honey in boiling water instead of tea. Ruby xx
Posts.Title: Digestive problems

Posts.Content: Hi Tina,  Not sure about the blood vessel part! you could always phone the breast care nurse, they are always very helpful and can explain things that you may have forgot to ask the consultant. Are you having chemo?  Ruby xx
Posts.Title: What does it mean when it has progressed in to blood vessels?

Posts.Content: Hi ladies  Felt I had to share a funny story with you all ( hopefully it will cheer you up). After having my mastectomy way back in 2005 I was in the supermarket with my partner we were stood at the check out waiting for our shopping to go through. The young girl kept looking at my chest then looking back at me and smiling then back at my chest. well at the time I was wearing a scarf as I had lost all my hair due to chemo and was sometimes a little paranoid about people staring at me. When we walked away my other half said "that was a bit rude, that girl was really staring at you" to which I replied " Ye I thought that too". As we walked out of the shop a huge smile appeared on my partners face which was followed by roars of laughter, as he told me my softie had slid down and had taken up residence on my tummy. We laughed for days afterwards. i hope that has given you all a wee chuckle. xxx
Posts.Title: Pain after axillary clearance

Posts.Content: Hi there Hope the recon goes well. I never had the courage to go through with it. I really wish I had now as I find summertime really difficult and my stick on boob starts to peel off in the heat. Let me know how you get on. Ruby xx
Posts.Title: Pain after axillary clearance

Posts.Content: Hi sheiky The pain and fear that we all carry around with us is so very heavy. Even now after all this time I still feel the affects of this dreadful and destructive illness. If it happened to me now I would have legged it out of there, as it has striped me of confidence. Hope Thursday goes well ( I know how scary it is) Lets keep laughing!! cause that's all you can do. xxx
Posts.Title: Pain after axillary clearance

Posts.Content: Hi flower, My name is Ruby  and I agree with Tracy about the rocking horse effect, you need to try and take a deep breath, step back and try not to let your mind go racing ahead of its self. maggies is a great place for any questions you have and just to have a cuppa and a chat . I am near Edinburgh so I sometimes go to the one at the Western General, I am a lot further down the line to a lot of the ladies on here, I guess I am nearly one of the statistics, I was only 34 when I was first diagnosed. The waiting bit is very hard to deal with but as many have said once the consultants decide what treatments is for you, you will then have that to focus on. I personally think by talking and maybe keeping a diary (daily or weekly) will help.  Also as regards to  going to GP's about anti depressants I would let the water settle for a bit before doing this, I think talking to someone about everything is a good thing, try Maggies and see how you get on. Will be thinking of you Big hugs Ruby xxx
Posts.Title: Age 37 shock at breast clinic yesterday. totally dazed and reeling...

Posts.Content: Hi Mickip  My name is Ruby I had Her2 pos cancer in 2004 I was 34, I am now 40 and still going. I had two different lots of chemo at different stages then radio and a years worth of herceptin which I am so very grateful. I know this is a frightening time but stay strong and KEEP FIGHTING this bloody awful illness. i am happy to answer you have about the herceptin or anything else. Ruby  xx
Posts.Title: her2 positive help

Posts.Content: That's fantastic news Annabel, so pleased, it can be the uplift that you need !!! Roobs xxx
Posts.Title: shrinking lump!!!!!!

Posts.Content: Here is your little bit of positivity, you are being proactive and taking back a little bit of control and that's got to make you feel a little better. Sending you much love and lots of hugs Annie xxxx Roobs x
Posts.Title: Not great scan results :(

Posts.Content: Having a bit of a moment and feeling very worried about an appointment with my surgeon which is next week.  I had a mastectomy in June 2005 and full axillary clearance everything went fine. Fast forward to about three weeks ago and my hand has been swelling which is not unusual as it does from time to time but this time it was not getting any better. Last Thursday I ended up calling the doctor out as it had become pale and cold.  To my shock and absolute horror he told me that I would have to go to hospital as there may be a chance I could have a blood clot.  So got to the hospital and they did some blood tests and found there was no blood clot and sent me home with some very strong antibiotic. Spoke to BCN and she said that the surgeon would want to see me just to make sure that everything was ok and although the hand is much better I am  scared beyond belief and can't stop shaking. Partner just keeps saying everything will be fine cause he is worried and does not know how to handle it, plus I have to try and keep it together for my 11year old son. Help need some advice !!!!!!
Posts.Title: SO FRIGHTENED, HAVING A BIT OF A MOMENT

Posts.Content: Hi Caroline I am now on my second set of five year Tamoxifen after having a two year break from it, my hot flushes came back until my breast nurse told me to take the tablet in the morning rather than night and I have to say it's worked for me, although you didn't mention if you were on Tamoxifen, good luck with trying it. x
Posts.Title: Hot flushes/sweats

Posts.Content: Oh Ellen  you have actually brought me to tears! (where did that come from)?                                          I think your amazingly brave and I mean that from the bottom of my heart.  I cant even begin to imagine how you must feel the second time around. Can I ask when you went into the menopause? that is if you have Im guessing you have? Hope daughter is ok and the other one is looking after you. ;) Ruby xx
Posts.Title: has shaved my head ! :)

Posts.Content: Well suprise suprise I hate flying and Im the biggest control freak LOL.  My other half used to call me monica from friends! But Im not like that anymore there are more important things in life than house work and getting things perfect. Im having some councelling after chrimbo so hopefully that will help. Hope you stay well and have a good sleep tonight. Talk soon xxx night night :)
Posts.Title: has shaved my head ! :)

Posts.Content: Sorry it just touched a raw  nerve. I don't think stopping taking it a year short made it come back, we will probably never have answers to any of it. I must say on the hair thingy I loved the fact that I didn't have to fuss over my hair and no waxing down below. Also I used to wear really cool funky head scarfs. How did you get past the panic attacks? x
Posts.Title: has shaved my head ! :)

Posts.Content: Hi Ellen I have just read your first post on here and it took me back to when I was losing my hair and my best friend was a hair dresser (Thank god)  I had a few of my closest friends over one night and we decided it was time to get the clippers out. I had had very long hair until I was  advised by my chemo nurse to maybe get it cut short so it would not be such a shock for when it did fall out which I did and that was ok, but then we had our night of shaving and although there were tears shed by the girls they were more about the cancer rather than my hair, infact I found it quiet lberating and at the end of the day it will grow back!!! I also used to get neutropenic and have to spend days in hospital, which was so boring cause I was always put in a side room. Good luck with your counts, hope you manage to stay out of hospital, oh and Happy late BDAY. Ruby xxx
Posts.Title: has shaved my head ! :)
